Situation1: The meeting is the final discussion before major decisions are locked in.
Situation2: They see a group of teenagers ignoring the no-diving signs near the pool edge.
Story: I sat at the edge of the pool, my laptop balanced on my knees, trying to focus on the team meeting streaming through my earbuds. This was the final discussion before we locked in the project’s direction, and my manager had made it clear that everyone’s input was crucial. I was expected to participate, to show I was engaged and committed. But as I listened, my eyes kept darting to the far end of the pool, where a group of teenagers had started gathering. They were laughing, pushing each other, and I saw one of them glance at the no-diving sign before climbing onto the edge. My heart pounded. As a lifeguard, I was responsible for enforcing safety rules, and I knew how quickly things could go wrong. I could hear my name being called in the meeting, waiting for my thoughts on the proposal, but I couldn’t tear my eyes away from the kids. The pressure from both sides pressed in on me, and I felt torn, knowing I couldn’t meet both expectations at once.
